moves.1. d4 e5: Black plays an unusual response to my first move, presumably trying to get away from the "book" lines.
moves.2. dxe5 d6: Now I have a chance to cement an early material advantage without falling behind in development.
moves.4. e4: ...and the game proper begins. With both center Pawns out of the way I can develop quickly.
moves.4... b6 5. Nc3: Aiming at Q5. As long as I can prevent ...P-Q4 my KP will give me a space advantage in the center.
moves.10... d5 11. exd5: ..but first I have to deal with Black's Pawn thrust....
moves.11... Ne5 12. Nf3: ...and now I want to exchange and get *Black's* knight out of the center.
moves.12... Nxf3+ 13. Qxf3: Down 2 Pawns, Black obligingly exchanges for me, bringing my Queen out without loss of time.
moves.13... Qd8 14. Rfe1: Pinning the B and virtually forcing Black to castle.
moves.14... O-O 15. Qh3: With Black's K where it is, if I can just get rid of his Knight I could play QxP mate. H'mmm...
moves.15... Bc8 16. Qh4: Black doesn't see my threat. He thinks I merely moved the Q to get it out from the Bishop's fire.
moves.16... a5: Now mate or serious material loss is inevitable. 16... P-KR3! drives the QB and kills the mate threat.
moves.17. Bxf6: Black can play 17... P-R3 [or 17... P-N3] stopping the mate, but after 18 BxB forking Q and R he would be hopelessly behind in material. 17... PxB still falls to 18 QxP mate. 17... R-K1 merely delays it by a move [18 QxP ch K-B1 19 Q-R8 mate.]
moves.17... Bxf6: Not seeing the threat, he completes the exchange of minor pieces.
